results.title: Winnie the Pooh discovers the seasons
results.creator_credit: Ennis McNutty, Rick Reinert and Walt Disney
results.brief_description: Christopher Robin gives Winnie the Pooh a calendar to keep track of days and seasons. Winnie and his friends discover the joys of long, warm days and Winnie learns about hibernation from the Wise Owl. With songs and music.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ennis McNutty, Rick Reinert and Walt Disney

results.title: Winnie the Pooh and Tigger too
results.creator_credit: John Lounsbery, Wolfgang Reitherman and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Rambunctious Tigger bounces his way through this film, leaving a trail of laughter and enjoyment behind him. Poor Rabbit, driven to distraction by Tigger’s high spirits plot’s a “calming sort of lesson”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Lounsbery, Wolfgang Reitherman and Walt Disney Productions

results.title: Twin Peaks. Season one. Eps 5-7 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Caleb Deschanel, Lesli Glatter, Mark Frost, Gregg Fienberg, Frost Productions and Lynch/Frost Productions
results.brief_description: Ep 5: In this episode, Agent Cooper and Sheriff Truman discover several new leads which point to the involvement of Leo Johnson and Jacques Renault in Laura’s murder. Audrey Horne continues to provide more unexpected assistance to the investigation as she infiltrates the nearby brothel, One-Eyed Jacks, in an effort to impress Agent Cooper. Meanwhile, Donna forms a new bond with James Hurley and Madeline, while Laura’s father, Leland Palmer, becomes even more unhinged. Ep 6: Agent Cooper and Big Ed Hurley, James’ uncle, go undercover at the casino and brothel, One-Eyed Jacks, unaware of Audrey’s similar plans. Meanwhile James Hurley and Donna Hayward, suspicious of Laura’s psychiatrist, Dr. Jacoby, decide to lay a trap for him by disguising Madeline as Laura, back from the dead. Ep 7: The final episode of the first season sees the climax of several important plotlines. Donna and James’ trap for Dr. Jacoby backfires after he is beaten and has a heart attack. Agent Cooper’s undercover infiltration of One-Eyed Jacks leads to a telling encounter with Jacques Renault, who confesses to his activities on the night of Laura’s murder. Meanwhile, Leo Johnson sets fire to the mill with his wife inside, unknowing of the plans for his own demise.

results.title: Twice dead
results.creator_credit: Bert Dragin, Guy Louthan, Robert McDonnell and Concorde Pictures
results.brief_description: A family learn the grisly cost of their inheritance when the mansion they take possession of proves to be the house from hell. By day they are harassed by a vigilante street gang, by night they are visited by the ghostly apparition of a dead actor. It’s a choice between two evils when both night and day present equally horrific forms of evil. Cast includes Tom Breznahan, Jill Whitlow, Jonathan Chapin and Christopher Burgard.

results.title: TwentyFourSeven = 24 7
results.creator_credit: Shane Meadows, Imogen West, BBC Film Unit, October Films and Scala
results.brief_description: TwentyFourSeven marks the screen debut of writer/director Shane Meadows with an assuredness and humour about working/under class people that is also to be a theme in subsequent films (“A Room for Romeo Brass”). Shot in black and white, the lack of colour adds to the washed-out public housing development in which unemployed families pass the time, time that does nothing to change their situations. Darcy (Bob Hoskins) fondly remembers in his youth that a boxing club gave him some hope, so he sets about combining the local gangs to form a youth club. Moments of humour in the script provide lighter distractions as the weight of the whole film and its import in post-Thatcher’s Britain can sit heavily with viewer. Among the failures and hopelessness, camaraderie and self-respect are not all lost along with demise of the club and Darcy’s descent into alcoholism. Great soundtrack, with a cast that includes: Frank Harper, Karl Collins, Bruce Jones and Danny Nussbaum. Co-written by Paul Fraser.

results.title: Whale rider. Cracker bag
results.creator_credit: Glendyn Ivin, Niki Caro, Frank Hubner, Jane Liscombe, John Barnett, Tim Sanders, Apollo Media, Exit Films, Outerspace, Pandora Films, Ruby Films and South Pacific Pictures
results.brief_description: Whale Rider: Set in a small village in rural New Zealand, “Whale Rider” is the story of a Maori community who are looking for a new male heir as leader. All looks certain until the heir apparent and his mother die at childbirth leaving his twin, Pai, a baby girl. Pai (Keisha Castle-Hughes) has to overcome 1000 years of tradition and the fierce determination of her beloved grandfather to assert her rightful place as leader and re-unite her people. Beautiful landscapes, moody music and underwater photography add to the lush look of this film. Internationally acclaimed and multi-award winning feature film. Based on the novel “The Whale Rider” by Witi Ihmaera. “Cracker bag”: Personal childhood memories are evoked when watching this Australian short about a young girl, Eddie, as she saves her money to buy fireworks for Guy Fawkes Night. Set in the 1980s, “Cracker Bag” is a tender suburban study that finely depicts a disheartening pivotal moment in the life of a young girl. Photographic-like in its 35mm presentation, “Cracker bag” is deservedly Winner of the Palme D’Or (Short Film) Festival De Cannes 2003 and many other accolades. Written and directed by Glendyn Ivin, starring young Edith Cattell as Eddie.

results.title: Whale hunting
results.creator_credit: Mosha Michael, Peter Raymont and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An interesting and informative journey with six Inuit hunters in their hunt of the Beluga whale near Frobisher Bay, N.W.T. We learn about the methods used in pursuing the whale and dividing the carcass.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mosha Michael, Peter Raymont and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Tokyo girls [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Penelope Buitenhuis, Gillian Darling Kovanic and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Japan, the land of the geisha, is now attracting young foreign women from across a broad spectrum to work as hostesses in the Tokyo nightclubs, of which there are around 11,000 hostess clubs registered in Tokyo. In this documentary, four young Canadian women - Hillary, Jamie, Nancy and Dhana - candidly talk about their own personal experiences as hostesses and how it has affected them in the long term. All agreed that money was the motivation and that customer/hostess relationships are purely fiscal and non-emotional, although certainly the occasional relationship among some hostesses and their customers did take place. The documentary explores the cross-cultural issues comparing the traditional “geisha” to the hostesses or “economy geisha” as they are often referred to and includes interviews with a variety of people, both Japanese and westerners, involved with this fascinating Japanese tradition. Parties, alcohol, money and occasionally, sex, hostesses often live the lavish life. They are highly-paid and well sought after, particularly if they happen to be tall and blonde. The glitz and glamour however, can soon lose its appeal as money paid becomes money spent on drugs, mainly speed, as hostesses sometimes begin to “lose the plot”. Shot in Canada, Osaka and Tokyo, “Tokyo girls” is visually captivating and supported by a great soundtrack, providing a rare inside look at the old and the new, the traditional and the commercial, the upside and the downside of a culture still highly valued (by Japanese men) and still being practised today in Japan. In English and French with English subtitles.

results.title: Tom Brown's School Days
results.brief_description: In this marvellous Hollywood version of British public school life, Tom Brown finds life at Rugby brutal, but eventually helps to become a civilising influence for his schoolmates. Immediately on arrival at Rugby, Tom is befriended by a character named East and together they begin the age old battle against the schoolyard bully. This classic novel is a story of courage, survival of the initiation ritual, and the struggle for acceptance.

results.title: Token gesture
results.creator_credit: Micheline Lanctot, Julie McGregor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Witty and animated look at sex-role stereotypes and conditioning, examining the historical development of these attitudes starting at birth and continuing through adulthood. Also looks at the tokenism of some gestures made to establish more flexibility in these roles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Micheline Lanctot, Julie McGregor and National Film Board of Canada
